0: The judge in former Trump campaign chairman Paul Manafort Paul John ManafortTop Dem on Senate Russia probe decorates house for ‘witch hunt’ on Halloween Trump says he has not received subpoena from Mueller Trump complained about Mueller investigation in final meeting with McGahn: report MORE’s trial suggested to a prosecutor for special counsel Robert Mueller Robert Swan MuellerSasse: US should applaud choice of Mueller to lead Russia probe MORE that he is “so frustrated” that there were tears in his eyes. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Bloomberg reported that U.S. District Judge T.S. Ellis III made the comment to prosecutor Greg Andres during a discussion out of earshot of the jury and members of the media. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR ADVERTISEMENT NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR “I understand how frustrated you are,” Ellis said. “In fact, there’s tears in your eyes right now.’’ NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Andres disputed Ellis’s statement, to which the judge replied, “Well, they’re watery.” NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Tensions have existed between the prosecutors and Ellis throughout the trial. The judge has asked members of both sides to refrain from making facial expressions that might influence the jury. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR He has also criticized Mueller’s team for presenting too much evidence on Manafort’s spending, arguing that spending on luxuries is not a crime. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Bloomberg reported that Ellis and Andres had other tense private conversations during the trial on Monday, during which former Manafort associate Richard Gates testified that he and Manafort committed crimes. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Andres claimed that Ellis was preventing him from asking essential questions for the trial. Ellis disputed that he was prioritizing speed over the prosecutor’s arguments. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The pair have had other confrontations during the trial, according to Bloomberg. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR “Look at me when you’re talking to me,’’ Ellis said to Andres at one point. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR “I’m sorry, judge, I was,’’ the prosecutor replied. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR “No, you weren’t,’’ Ellis said. “You were looking down.’’ NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR “Because I don’t want to get in trouble for some facial expression,’’ Andres said. “I don’t want to get yelled at again by the court for having some facial expression when I’m not doing anything wrong, but trying my case." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Manafort is on trial for alleged financial crimes related to his work for a pro-Russia political party in Ukraine.
